author: N Anand
text:
The banking system came to a grinding halt on Friday with nearly 3.50 lakh employees owing allegiance to the All India Bank Employees’ Association (AIBEA) taking part in the nationwide strike. As a result, customers were unable to deposit or withdraw cash in branches. The strike also affected other basic services.

21 lakh cheques uncleared

About 21 lakh cheques worth about Rs.16,000 crore could not be cleared, said AIBEA general secretary C.H. Venkatachalam.

The strike was to protest against the actions of five associate banks (State Bank of Mysore, State Bank of Travancore, State Bank of Hyderabad, State Bank of Patiala and State Bank of Bikaner & Jaipur) that went against the industry-level settlement on wages and service conditions signed in June 2015.

“The strike was forced on us because of the adamant approach of the management. We hope that the government and the Indian Banks’ Association will resolve the demands of the employees,” Mr. Venkatachalam said.

AIBEA officials claimed that the strike was a total success in major metros and in secondary cities. The office-bearers will meet in Chennai on January 13 to take further decision.
title: Strike brings banking operations to a halt
